result.markdown:
# Sentinel Common Data Model :::{.panel-tabset} ## ENR ### Enrollment The SCDM Enrollment Table has a start/stop structure that contains one record per continuous enrollment period. Patients with medical coverage, drug coverage, or both should be included. A break in enrollment (of at least one day) or a change in either the medical or drug coverage variables should generate a new record. Unique Row: PatID, Enr_Start, Enr_End, MedCov, DrugCov, Chart Sort Order: PatID, Enr_Start, Enr_End, MedCov, DrugCov, Chart
Variable Name Variable Type and Length (Bytes) Values Missing Values Allowed? Definition Guidance Example
PatID[^PatID is a pseudoidentifier with a consistent crosswalk to the true identifier retained by the source Data Partner. For analytical data sets requiring patient-level data, only the pseudoidentifier is used to link across all information belonging to a patient.] Num(#) Unique patient identifier No Arbitrary person-level identifier Note 1: A new enrollment period generates a new record, but the same person should have the same PatID on subsequent records.
Note 2: Use the fewest number of bytes necessary to hold all distinct values; see "SAS Lengths" Reference Table. 		123456789
Enr_Start[^Adjacent and overlapping enrollment periods with the same PatID, Enr_Start, Enr_End, MedCov, DrugCov, and Chart values should be collapsed. Enrollment periods separated by more than one day should not be bridged. For example, an Enr_End date of 1/31/2019 should be bridged with an Enr_Start date of 2/1/2019, but should not be bridged with an Enr_Start date of 2/2/2019.] Num(4) SAS Date No Date of the beginning of the enrollment period. Note 1: If the exact date is unknown, use the first day of the month.
Note 2: Enr_Start should not be before January 1, 2000. 		1/1/2019
Enr_End[^Enr_End should not be imputed using the date of death found in the Death table.] Num(4) SAS Date No Date of the end of the enrollment period. Note 1: If the exact date is unknown, use the last day of the month. 12/31/2019
MedCov Char(1) Y = Yes
N = No
U = Unknown
A = Ambulatory Only 		No Indicates whether the patient has medical coverage during the enrollment period. Note: Mark as Y if the health plan has any responsibility for covering medical care for the member during this enrollment period (i.e., if you expect to observe medical care provided to this member during the enrollment period). Mark as A if only ambulatory visit coverage is provided. Y
DrugCov Char(1) Y = Yes
N = No
U = Unknown 		No Indicates whether the patient has drug coverage during the enrollment period. Note: Mark as Y if the health plan has any responsibility for covering outpatient prescription drugs for the member during this enrollment period (i.e., if you expect to observe outpatient pharmacy dispensings for this member during this enrollment period). Y
Chart[^This flag does not address chart availability.][^This flag does not address chart availability.] Char(1) Y = Yes
N = No 		No Chart abstraction flag to answer the question, "Are you able to request charts for this member?" Note: Mark as Y if the health plan is able to request charts for this member. Mark as N if the health plan is not able to request charts for this member. Y
## DEM ### Demographic The SCDM Demographic Table contains one record per PatID with the most recent information on Birth_Date, Sex, Race, and PostalCode. Unique Row: PatID Sort Order: PatID
Variable Name Variable Type and Length (Bytes) Values Missing Values Allowed? Definition Guidance Example
PatID[^PatID is a pseudoidentifier with a consistent crosswalk to the true identifier retained by the source Data Partner. For analytical data sets requiring patient-level data, only the pseudoidentifier is used to link across all information belonging to a patient.] Num(#) Unique patient identifier No Arbitrary person-level identifier Note: Use the fewest number of bytes necessary to hold all distinct values; see "SAS Lengths" Reference Table. 123456789
Birth_Date Num(4) SAS Date Yes Date of birth. 12/5/1971
Sex[^The Sex variable is populated with biological sex data, which may not be correlated with gender.] Char(1) A = Ambiguous
F = Female
M = Male
U = Unknown 		No Sex. F
Hispanic[^At this time the SCDM retains one Race and one Hispanic value per individual.] Char(1) Y = Yes
N = No
U = Unknown 		No A person of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race. N
Race[^At this time the SCDM retains one Race and one Hispanic value per individual.] Char(1) 0 = Unknown
1 = American Indian or Alaska Native (A person having origins in any of the original peoples of North and South America (including Central America), and who maintains tribal affiliation or community attachment.
2 = Asian (A person having origins in any of the original peoples of the Far East, Southeast Asia, or the Indian subcontinent including, for example, Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippine Islands, Thailand, and Vietnam.)
3 = Black or African American (A person having origins in any of the black racial groups of Africa.)
4 = Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander (A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, or other Pacific Islands.)
5 = White (A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa.)
M = Multi-racial (A person who identifies with two or more races.) 		No Race. Note: Please use only one race value per patient. 2
PostalCode Char(#) Postal/Region Code Yes Postal code of patient's most recent primary residence. USA: First 5 digits of the ZIP code of the patient's most recent primary residence. (5 characters only)
Other: Complete postal code or region identifier. (variable length is dependent on code length) 		04090
PostalCode_Date Num(4) SAS Date Yes Earliest date that the PostalCode is believed to be continuously correct up until the end date of your source data for the ETL. Date will be updated/overwritten as postal code for a patient/member changes over time. 12/12/2009
## DIS ### Dispensing The SCDM Outpatient Pharmacy Dispensing Table contains one record per unique outpatient pharmacy dispensing. Rollback transactions and other adjustments should be processed before populating this table Unique Row: PatID, RxDate, Rx_CodeType, Rx, ProviderID Sort Order: PatID, RxDate
Variable Name Variable Type and Length (Bytes) Values Missing Values Allowed? Definition Guidance Example
PatID[^PatID is a pseudoidentifier with a consistent crosswalk to the true identifier retained by the source Data Partner. For analytical data sets requiring patient-level data, only the pseudoidentifier is used to link across all information belonging to a patient.] Num(#) Unique patient identifier No Arbitrary person-level identifier. Used to link across tables. Note: Use the fewest number of bytes necessary to hold all distinct values; see "SAS Lengths" Reference Table. 123456789
ProviderID[^As with the PatID, the ProviderID is a pseudoidentifier with a consistent crosswalk to the real identifier.][^As with the PatID, the ProviderID is a pseudoidentifier with a consistent crosswalk to the real identifier.] Num(#) Unique provider identifier
.U = SAS Special Missing value indicating an individual provider or prescriber cannot be identified. 		No Identifier for the individual provider who prescribed the drug. Note: If an individual provider/prescriber can not be identified, set to special missing value .U. This variable links to the Provider table. Use the fewest number of bytes necessary to hold all distinct values; see "SAS Lengths" Reference Table. 12345
RxDate Num(4) SAS Date No Dispensing date (as close as possible to date the person received the dispensing). 11/29/2005
Rx Char(#) Drug Code No Code representing a prescribed medication or medical device. Note 1: Please expunge any place holders (e.g., "-" or extra digits).
Note 2: Use the fewest number of bytes necessary to hold all values for all values of RxCodeType; see "SAS Lengths" Reference Table. 		00006007431
Rx_CodeType[^Rx_CodeType includes options for values that are relevant to medication and medical device codes used in different international jurisdictions.] Char(2) ND = National Drug Code (US)
SN = SNOMED-CT (US)
SK = SNOMED-CT (UK/CPRD)
DM = Dictionary of Medicines and Devices (UK)
DI = Drug Identification Number (CA)
RN = RxNorm (US)
AT = Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical Classification System (DK) 		No Code type of prescribed medication or medical device. This field combined with the Rx field should be used to capture any type of prescribed medication or medical device available in the source data. Other code types may be added as new terminologies are used. SK
RxSup Num(4) Days Supply Yes Number of days that the medication supports based on the number of doses as reported by the pharmacist. Note 1: This amount is typically found on the dispensings record. It should not be necessary to calculate this variable for use in the SCDM.
Note 2: Positive integer values are expected 		30
RxAmt Num(4) Amount Dispensed Yes Number of units (pills, tablets, vials) dispensed. Net amount per dispensing. Note 1: This amount is typically found on the dispensings record. It should not be necessary to calculate this variable for use in the SCDM.
Note 2: Positive values are expected 		60
:::
